document.docAuthor: Yamana, Yusuke, Nakaguchi, Kazumitsu, Yamaguchi, Shuhei, Katoh, Mikio, Ogawa, Akito & Ohtsuka, Susumu
document.docTitle: Thyone toyoshiomaruae Yamana, Ogawa & Ohtsuka 2021, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Four new dendrochirotid holothurians collected from the Seto Inland Sea and the western part of the Sea of Japan, western Japan

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Four new dendrochirotid holothurians collected from the Seto Inland Sea and the western part of the Sea of Japan, western Japan

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined.
Holotype
, WMNH-INV-2015-2483 (ST- 11 in 2015, length 46 mm , width 7 mm , INSD accession number LC528686 , 514 bps, Fig. 2 D-m)
.
Paratypes
: WMNH-INV-2015-2484 (ST- 11 in 2015, anesthetized length 14 mm , width 2 mm , Fig. 2 D-n); WMNH-INV-2015-2438 (ST- 3 in 2015, length 15 mm , width 4 mm , posterior only, Fig. 2 D-k); WMNH-INV-2015-2439 (ST- 3 in 2015, length 7 mm , width 1 mm , Fig. 2 D-l).
Diagnosis. Bodywalltable ossicles, with regular, oval disc with four large central perforations and small peripheral ones, low two-pillared spires with one crossbeam and 4–8 minute apical spines.

Description. Body medium, up to 46 mm , fusiform, curved, with both ends tapered and turned slightly upwards ( Fig. 2D ); bodywall thick, soft. Living body color pale orange or pale olive-brownish, not seriously affected by fixation/preservation. Tentacles 10, arranged in a single circle, medioventral two tentacles smaller than the other eight. Live color of tentacles and introvert same as body in most parts. One row of short villi surrounding oral opening. Color of oral periphery and mouth brown. Pedicels minute, not retractile, covering entire body at constant density, lacking in introvert region. Color of pedicels same or slightly paler than adjacent body. Pedicels becoming gradually smaller anteriorly and posteriorly from middle portion of body. Ten anal papillae and five anal teeth on radii. After preservation in ethanol, color turned slightly paler than that of living state.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 7. Scanning electron microscope images of ossicles of
Thyone toyoshiomaruae
sp. nov.
( holotype , A–I, WMNH- INV-2015-2483). A, ossicles of the ventrolateral tentacle; B, the ventrolateral skin of peri-oral; C, the ventrolateral skin of pharynx; D, the ventrolateral introvert skin; E the pedicel of the abdominal side; F and G, the middle part of the bodywall on the abdominal and dorsal side, respectively; H, the ventrolateral anal papilla.

TABLE 6. Counts and measurements (Mean ± sd μm) of ossicles from four specimens of
Thyone toyoshiomaruae
sp. nov.

paragraph.tableNote: WMNH-INV: Invertebrate collection of the Wakayama Prefectural Museum of Natural History.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Table 7. Congeneric comparison of the morphologies amongst all the species of
Massinium Samyn & Thandar, 2003

tr.td: Ossicle types and size range (μm, ossicles long) reported at each body part Tentacle Peri-oral Introvert Bodywall
Tables (70–90 μm long disc), rarely rosettes (20–25 μm)
Rods, rosette-like plates and pseudobut- tons (15–50 μm)
Gray in life off-white in preserved
Tables and Rods (up to 90 µm) rosette like rods (up to 88 µm)
Yellowish brown with dark brown/gray punctua- tion
Tables (80–100 μm long disc) and rosettes (20–50 μm)
Only tables with a single pillared spire
Light-yellow to off-white mottled with dark brown
Thin rods in branch, trunk lacking ossicles
Oval table discs with two- pillared spire
Yellowish-brown with dark brown/gray pigmen- tation,
Thin rods in branches, regular tables in roots
Variable, pale pinkish- brown with dark brown patches to uniform pale brown
Rods (up to 80 μm) disappearing with age frequently
Rosettes and tables (up to 96 μm long disc)

tableNote.paragraph: a References: C (1988), Cherbonnier, G. 1988; L (1882), Ludwig, H. 1882; OBV (2012), O’Loughlin, P. M., Barmos, S., and VandenSpiegel, D. 2012; OMV (2014), O’Loughlin, P. M., Mackenzie, M., and
VandenSpiegel, D. 2014; STV (2010), Samyn, Y., Thandar, A.S., and VandenSpiegel, D. 2010; ST (2003), Samyn, Y. and Thandar, A. S. 2003; T (1989), Thandar, A. S. 1989, YOKY; Yamana, Y., Ota,Y.,
Kohtsuka, H., Yoshizaki, K. 2020, nr: not reported, PV: Numbers of the Polian vesicles, SC: Numbers of the Stone canal.

subSubSection.paragraph: Bodywall with abundant tables ( Fig. 7F, G , Table 6 ), with oval disc and low, two-pillared spire, one crossbeam and 4–8 minute apical spines. Table disc with 4–9 (mostly 6-8) perforations, four large central ones and small peripheral ones.

Tentacles with rods, plates, and intermediate forms, varying in size and shape ( Fig. 7A , Table 6 ). Some plates of complex shapes, occasionally possessing several free-branches, resulting in rosette-like forms. Peri-oral skin with small rosettes, with numerous short branches, and with regular tables adjacent to tentacle bases ( Fig. 7B , Table 6 ). Tables with two pillars, mostly with 1–2 crossbeams, ending in 2–4 apical spines, occasionally the two pillars are united into one. Table disc oval with undulant margin, with four large central and 0–11 (mostly 4–5) small peripheral perforations. Pharyngeal villi with numerous, small, short, branching rosettes ( Fig. 7C , Table 6 ). Introvert with tables and rosettes ( Fig. 7D , Table 6 ). Tables with distorted, oval discs with undulating margins, with four large central, 4–12 (mostly 4–8) small peripheral perforations. Table with two, high pillars, mostly with two crossbeams and 2–8 minute apical spines, occasionally with low spires with only one crossbeam and rudimentary apical spines. Rosettes, medium size, with numerous, short branches.

Most pedicels with endplate and supporting tables ( Fig. 7E , Table 6 ). Supporting table discs distorted, oval or rhomboidal, with unduling margin, weakly arced, with 2–4 large central and 2–8 small distal perforations. Supporting tables with two pillars with one crossbeam, ending in 4–8 minute processes. Endplate brittle, with approximately three rings of holes, viz. , commarginally elongated holes near rim, radially elongated ones in mid-region, and almost circular ones in central area. Anal papilla with various shaped supporting plates ( Fig.7H , Table 6 ). Skin around anus with regular tables, with distorted, oval discs with undulating margins, with four large central and 3-10 (mostly 4-8) small peripheral perforations, two pillars with one crossbeam, and 4–8 minute apical spines.

Remarks.
Thyone toyoshiomaruae
sp. nov.
is most similar to
T. villosa Semper, 1867
. Both species have thin, crowded pedicels that cover the entire body, an olive-brownish color, and one long Polian vesicle (Table 8). However the new species differs from
T. villosa
in its bodywall ossicles:
T. villosa
has table ossicles with single pillars, ending in one cluster of four or five minute apical spines ( Semper 1867 –1868; Panning 1949 ) (Table 8), whereas the new species,
T. toyoshiomaruae
, has table ossicles with two-pillars ending in two clusters of 2–4 minute apical spines. Tips of pillars in the new species are usually bifurcated and not fused into united single spire. The new species is also similar to
T. papuensis
(in Théel, 1886 ) (presently known as
deichmannae
) in that their body ossicles possessing oval disc with low spire and four large central holes and small perforation at each corner, however the pedicel supporting tables of
T. papuensis
are unique form in their outline, supporting tables with rod-like disc ( Théel 1886 ) (Table 8). Additionally, the tentacles of
T. papuensis
have smooth rod ossicles only ( Liao & Pawson 2001 ), quite unlike the rods and plates of the present new species.

Distribution. The western part of the Sea of Japan , depth 78–87 m , on sand and muddy sand bottoms. Western part of the Sea of Japan , depth 87 m , sand bottom (ST- 11 in 2015) and depth 78 m , muddy sand bottom (ST- 3 in 2015).

Etymology. The specific name
toyoshiomaruae
alludes to the name TR/V TOYOSHIO MARU of Hiroshima University.

Molecular data comparison. In BLAST searches, the closest hit to the partial COI sequence is from
Thyone pedata
(INSD accession number KF142165 , NMV F173267, National Museum Victoria Australia , 83.0% similarity with 96% coverage). The results of BLAST searches supports that the present species belongs to
Thyone
.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 8-2. Congeneric comparison of the ossicles morphologies of bodywall and tentacles, amongst the presently nominated species of
Thyone Oken, 1815
.

tr.td: Characteristics of the two-pillared table in the bodywall (values are approximate values) Approx. table height Typical number of Spire top Bodywall table disc shape (No. crossbeams) disc holes
Characteristics of the tentacles rosettes / rods (values are approximate values)
Oval oblong discs, with a handle on the inner side, with thickened edge
Simple liner rods, approx. 70–250 µm long, with several distal perforations on both ends
nr (This species elected by the basis of external morphologies)
nr (This species elected by the basis of external morphologies)

The same to
T. fusus
, or slightly larger than their ossicles. Inner layer of the bodywall possessing plates with four holes.
Irregular-formed rosettes or rosette-like plates, variable
Rhombus, rectangule or elliptical, 40–70 µm long discs, marginally smooth
Elongated rosettes, 30 µm long. Thin rods with distal perforations, 30–40 µm long
Spiny oblong top with minute teeth
Roundish-quadeate disc, 60 µm long, with a handle on the inner side
Numerous, elongated rosettes, small supporting rods with distal perforations
Supporting plates or elongated rosettes, 70 µm long, with many minute side branches
A few numbers of blunt spine
Rhombus or elliptical disc, 120–200 µm long, marginally smooth
Small rosette or reticulated plate, 70 µm long, smooth oblong thick rod or elongated plate, 220 µm long
Small rosettes, 20–60 µm long, and thin rods or elongated rosettes
Roundish-quadrate or roundish rhombus discs. Spire with united pillars
Short spire built up of short 2 pillars
Oval disc, often with thickened edge and a varying number of knobs
Small rods, 30–60 µm long, large rods 150 µm long, plates 140–220 µm long, rosettes, 30–60 µm long
Oval or roundish-quadrate rosettes, 50 µm long
Rectangle or elliptical disc, 80–120 µm long, marginally undulating
Few flat rods gathering in basal part, up to 120 µm long, with small numbers of perforations, gathering both ends
Pillars fused into one conical top
Marginally undulating Polygonal- shape disc, 100–150 µm long
In the distal part, thin rods, about 60 µm long, with many distal perforations. In the proximal part, oval rosettes, about 25 µm long reported
Short spire built up of fused 2 pillars
One blunt tip, with few teeth
Robust oblong disc, 72–118 µm long, with a handle or half-ring on the disc inner side
Tables with 2 strong pillars fused approximately 1/3 the way up their length tapering to a blunt tip, armed with 2–7 teeth
